Title: Analyzing Students’ Performance in Computerized Formative Assessments to Optimize Teachers’ Test Administration Decisions Using Deep Learning Frameworks
1.2 Context: Classroom setting with computerized formative assessments.
1.3 Tech/AI type: Deep learning frameworks, specifically Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through predictions of test administration based on students' performance history.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism aligns with formative assessment principles, focusing on optimizing test administration based on performance data.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; decisions are primarily made by the system and teachers based on predictions.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; it is determined by the system based on performance data.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.

3.1 Agency type: Self-directed learning agency
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students can control when they receive feedback.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Not specified

Title: Large Scale Assessments for Learning a Human Centred Ai Approach to Contextualizing Test Performance
1.2 Context: Large-scale assessments in a digital testing environment.
1.3 Tech/AI type: Human-centred AI (HAI) and machine learning techniques.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated from process profiles that analyze students' test-taking behaviors and performance.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is contextual and aims to inform educators about students' engagement and performance, which aligns with the paper's focus on understanding test-taking behaviors.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily directed at educators and policymakers.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores, process data, and engagement indicators.

Title: Improving the Validity of Automatically Generated Feedback via Reinforcement Learning
1.2 Context: Classroom and online learning platforms.
1.3 Tech/AI type: Large Language Models (LLMs) and Reinforcement Learning (RL).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated for incorrect student responses to math questions, focusing on correctness and pedagogical alignment.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback generated is aimed at being pedagogically valid, focusing on understanding errors and providing constructive suggestions.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily automated.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Rubric scores, ROUGE-L, BERTScore.

Title: Stimulating Individual Learning of the Concept of Fraction Equivalence
1.2 Context: Classroom, intervention setting.
1.4 Tool/Platform: Not specified by name, referred to as a digital learning environment.
2.1 Feedback term: Individualized feedback, explanatory feedback, corrective feedback.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided based on real-time process data, tailored to specific errors, and is given immediately after task completion.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is corrective and explanatory, aimed at enhancing understanding and addressing misconceptions.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students engage with tasks but may not fully control their learning paths.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is provided immediately after task completion.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Number of tasks completed, accuracy of solved tasks, perceived competence, and autonomy support.

Title: Incentivizing Supplemental Math Assignments and Using Ai Generated Hints Is Associated with Improved Exam Performance
1.2 Context: Classroom setting in an introductory physics course.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through AI-generated hints that guide students in problem-solving without giving away the full solution.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by AI-generated hints is supportive and aims to enhance problem-solving skills, aligning with formative assessment practices.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students can choose to use hints but are not required to.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; hints are available when they choose to access them.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Exam scores, completion rates of supplemental math assignments, and usage of AI-generated hints.

Title: Algebra Error Classification with Large Language Models
1.2 Context: Open-ended math questions in an algebra setting.
1.4 Tool/Platform: Cognitive Tutor and various LLMs (e.g., BERT, GPT-2).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated based on detected errors in student responses, which are classified into predefined error classes.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is immediate and tailored to specific errors, which aligns with the paper's focus on error classification. The quality of feedback is described as being able to direct students to the precise error in their problem-solving process.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students respond to feedback but do not control its generation.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification accuracy (percentage of correctly predicted classes).

Title: Constraint Based Student Modelling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques
1.2 Context: Classroom and online learning environment.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through highlighting keywords and offering hints based on student errors.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is specific and targeted, aimed at helping students understand their errors and correct them.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students can request hints and choose to answer scaffolding questions.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over feedback timing by choosing when to request hints.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, power learning curves.

Title: Effectiveness and Guidance of Artificial Intelligence Chatbots in Diagnosing Exponential Expression Errors
1.2 Context: The context is a classroom setting where students interact with chatbots to address misconceptions in mathematics.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through interactions with chatbots after students answer questions on exponential expressions. The feedback is triggered by students' responses to the conceptual test.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by the chatbots is intended to guide students in correcting misconceptions, but it sometimes lacks depth and accuracy.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students interact with chatbots but do not control the feedback process.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is provided after they submit their answers.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: The accuracy of student responses, the quality of explanations, and the level of confidence in responses.

Title: Development of a Generative Ai Powered Teachable Agent for Middle School Mathematics Learning a Design Based Research Study
1.2 Context: Authentic classroom settings.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided as students teach the agent, reflecting their understanding and effectiveness.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism aligns with the learning-by-teaching approach, promoting self-regulated learning.
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students take on the role of teachers.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Pre- and post-knowledge tests, usability surveys, and qualitative feedback.

Title: “i Didn’t Understand, I´m Really Not Very Smart”—how Design of a Digital Tutee’s Self Efficacy Affects Conversation and Student Behavior in a Digital Math Game
1.2 Context: Classroom setting, specifically during gameplay of a digital math game.
1.4 Tool/Platform: The Squares Family (name of the platform/game).
2.1 Feedback term: Feedback, recursive feedback, and self-efficacy feedback.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided after each game round, reflecting the digital tutee's self-efficacy, and is followed by a free format chat.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback aligns with the concept of recursive feedback, where the student infers their teaching effectiveness based on the tutee's performance. The quality of feedback is both implicit and explicit.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students can influence the tutee's learning but are primarily in a teaching role.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is predetermined by the game structure.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Frequency of responses to feedback, performance on multiple-choice questions, and goodness of card choices.
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the frequency and nature of student comments and responses to the tutee's feedback.

Title: Using Large Language Models to Diagnose Math Problem Solving Skills at Scale
1.2 Context: Classroom setting, specifically for elementary school students solving math word problems.
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided based on the diagnosis of students' answers compared to generated rubrics.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback is personalized and aims to improve students' problem-solving skills based on their specific answers.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily instructor-driven through the LLM.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Binary judgments (pass/fail) for each PERC competency.

Title: Contextual Factors Affecting Hint Utility
1.2 Context: Online mathematics assignments
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through hints that students can request while solving problems. Early access to hints is linked to improved performance.
2.3 Our evaluation: The paper suggests that early access to hints improves performance, indicating that the feedback is formative and adaptive.
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students can request hints but may not effectively use them.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not fully control feedback timing; it is dependent on their requests for hints.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Mastery speed, percent correct, total answer attempts, completion time
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured indirectly through help-seeking behavior and hint requests.

Title: Towards a Theoretical Foundation for Quality Tablet App Enriched Learning Environments in Primary School Mathematics Education
1.2 Context: Classroom and learning environments.
1.4 Tool/Platform: Specific tablet apps like "Klipp Klapp", "Klötzchen", and "TouchCounts".
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through interactions with the app, which can respond to student inputs.
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by the apps is adaptive and can guide students through their learning process.
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can make choices in their learning paths.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: The paper discusses qualitative analysis and coding of issues related to tablet apps.
